definition:
The *Burali-Forti* paradox demonstrates that the class of all ordinals
is not a set. If there were a set of all ordinals, $Ord$, then it would
follow that $Ord$ was itself an ordinal, and therefore that
$Ord\in Ord$. if sets in general are allowed to contain themselves,
ordinals cannot since they are defined so that $\in$ is well founded
over them.

This paradox is similar to both Russell’s paradox and Cantor’s paradox,
although it predates both. All of these paradoxes prove that a certain
object is “too large” to be a set.
